text: Over the last nine months, Kevin McCarthy worked with the extremists, not Democrats. America needs bipartisan leadership to tackle our greatest challenges like growing our economy, tackling climate change, and addressing both immigration and border security.

Democrats will continue to reach across the aisle on behalf of all Americans and the interests of our nation. We are committed to returning the House to working for the American people, now and into the future.
The former Speaker’s recalcitrance towards the Democrats marks a very sad day in the history of the House, and leaves the institution itself weaker.
Time and again, our calls for bipartisanship were rejected.

... who repeatedly demonstrated a willingness to work together.  All Democrats, and none more so than the nearly 100 members of the @NewDemCoalition, have stood with our hand extended, open to compromise.

I believe two things to be true:
1 the only way anything can become law in a divided Congress is with bipartisan collaboration
2 McCarthy’s Speakership failed because he sought to placate the duplicitous extremists in his party rather than seeking common ground with Democrats...

His sloppy rhetoric is the kind of misinformation that undermines America’s global leadership and should never be advanced by any member of Congress, let alone a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee.

I was shocked and deeply disappointed to watch my New York colleague @RepMikeLawler claim that the United States is in the business of holding hostages, like Russia and Iran. Let me be clear, the U.S. does not take hostages, does not hold hostages, denounces hostage-taking.
The next 45 days should be guided by bipartisan efforts to responsibly keep the government funded.

Now, I pray that Speaker McCarthy learns the lessons of this week’s Republican debacle and recognizes the obvious truth: the only way to fund the government is for Republicans and Democrats, in the House and Senate, to sit at the table, negotiate in good faith, and do the work.
Thanks to Democrats standing strong, the government will remain open and the vital programs Americans rely on, from Social Security to Medicare to our national parks, will continue to operate.

Earlier this week Republicans voted for, but could not pass, a temporary spending bill with nearly 30% across the board cuts: 30% cuts to community safety, 30% cuts to school nutrition, 30% cuts to foreign military assistance (including a $1 billion cut in funding to Israel).
Today, Democrats led the way in averting a reckless, unnecessary government shutdown—while also preventing devastating Republican cuts to critical federal programs.

Your community’s safety and our nation’s security is threatened because Kevin McCarthy only cares about having his name above the Speakers Office, not using his office to lead the Congress and serve the country.

McCarthy won’t take yes for an answer.

Not only are there 7, but all 98 New Dems have raised our hands to pass a bipartisan CR. If he brought the deal we already approved in May, he would have more than 300 votes in support.

He should either lead or get out of the way.

In an attempt to pass Speaker McCarthy's extreme bill to fund the government, 90% of House Republicans voted to cut Israel's security funding. The other 10% voted that the cut was not big enough. Israel's security is America's security. This vote was disgraceful.

Wishing all who are celebrating Rosh HaShanah a sweet and happy new year filled with good health, joy and peace.

His grotesque remarks add fuel to the rise of global antisemitism and undermine his own legitimacy as leader of the Palestinian Authority, the PLO and Fatah.

I stand resolutely with the Jewish, democratic state of Israel, and with the majority of Israelis, and their allies around the world, committed to advancing the fundamental Zionist ideal articulated 75 years ago in Israel’s Declaration of Independence.

While the U.S. commitment to Israel’s security is ironclad, the actions of the current government will undoubtedly strain Israel’s critical relationships with the diaspora Jewish community and the nations in which they all live.
The deep divide in Israeli society is only exacerbated by this move that unnecessarily puts Israel’s democracy and international standing in a precarious position.
I am deeply saddened and profoundly concerned by the decision of the coalition government in Israel to unilaterally move forward with dramatic and controversial changes to its judicial system.

We need to close the “ghost guns” loophole. Untraceable guns evade background checks and threaten public safety. This is not a partisan issue; we must do our job and pass this and other commonsense legislation to keep our communities safe.
... resulting in a Jewish, democratic Israel living side-by-side a viable, vibrant Palestinian state in peace, security and prosperity.
And, like President Herzog, I yearn for the conditions that will one day open the pathway for peace with the Palestinians through a directly negotiated two-state solution...

Throughout my life, I have prayed for a just and lasting peace for Israel and all the people of the region. I have joyously celebrated Israel’s peace agreements with Egypt, Jordan, and the Abraham Accords countries—the UAE, Bahrain, and Morocco.
Together, the United States and Israel must continue to work to ensure that Iran never succeeds in acquiring a nuclear weapon.
I share President Herzog’s concerns about Iran and his assessment that any capitulation to Iran in their pursuit of nuclear capabilities would be ‘an inexcusable moral collapse.’
Diverse citizens are represented in every facet of Israeli society, from the Knesset to the international U-20 soccer team.

Today, Israel is a vibrant democracy. As President Herzog pointed out, Israel is a state founded on the ‘complete equality of social and political rights to all its inhabitants irrespective of religion, race or sex.’
His representation of his country before the U.S. Congress is a remarkable symbol of the enduring and unshakable friendship of our two nations.
Almost 36 years later, Israel’s 11th president offered a sweeping vision that was a tremendous celebration of Israel’s historic and ironclad relationship with the United States.
President Herzog began his historic remarks reflecting that his late father, Chaim Herzog, Israel’s 6th president, stood in the exact same spot to address congress on November 10, 1987.

Lastly, I was proud to join my fellow co-chairs of the bipartisan, bicameral Congressional Abraham Accords Caucus in a meeting with President Herzog to talk about the importance of the Accords and the possibilities they open.
Following his remarks, I gathered with colleagues and community leaders with the President to celebrate his speech and the 75 year special relationship between the United States and Israel.

It was my great privilege today to join a standing room only audience to hear Israeli President Isaac Herzog deliver remarks to a joint session of Congress. I was particularly honored to be selected for the team to escort President Herzog into the House Chamber for his speech. 1/

If there’s anyone that the folks who are most critical of Israel should come listen to, it should be President Isaac Herzog. President Herzog is the one trying to find the common ground and bridge the differences to advance Israeli democracy.

As the representative for every Navy recruit and Vice-Chair of the New Democrat Coalition I could not in good conscience vote for such a dreadful, disingenuous and dangerous bill.
cnn.com/2023/07/14/politics/…
The majority’s amended bill attacks the health care of our service members, denigrates huge swaths of our country’s citizens, and will make our military less ready and less capable for the future.
Tragically, Speaker McCarthy’s decision this week to capitulate to the most extreme elements of his party made the original bipartisan bill unrecognizable.

The sweeping legislation would provide our service members the raises they deserve, and send a strong message to both our allies and our competitors guaranteeing America’s national defense and security.
I have always voted for the defense spending bill, and expected to again support the bipartisan package the House Armed Services Committee passed overwhelmingly, 58-1.

I know our military works best when every service member – regardless of gender, race, or ethnicity – is trusted, and empowered, to reflect the values and protect the security and interests of our great nation.
In my travels, I see the strength of our diversity, and the power of our unity in the brave men and women serving in uniform around the world.
In my district, I get to see the fullness of America’s diversity in the marching lines and dining halls at the Recruit Training Center at Naval Station Great Lakes.

We must not accept the extremist attacks on women’s health care, on our military's extraordinary reflection of America's rich diversity, and on America's leadership in defending democracy by capitulating to Putin in his invasion of Ukraine.

... and, for the first time ever, effectively abdicate the House’s role to the Senate? By giving in to the most radical members of his party, Speaker McCarthy would effectively silence our body's voice in advancing our military and protecting our nation.

The Republican majority will decide if the House will pass, as it always has, a bipartisan defense spending bill. Or will they allow extremist Republicans to so-politicize this year's bill that they would undermine America’s national security...
Just by my nature, I seek common ground and work towards sound legislation that benefits our entire country. Proposals by Matt Gaetz, Marjorie Taylor Greene, and Mary Miller tear at these efforts.

I have the privilege of representing Naval Station Great Lakes. As the father of a former Navy officer and as a New Dem, I have proudly voted for the NDAA every year. But the amendments proposed today are antithetical to a strong American military.

Working with our Israeli allies, the US must help develop a comprehensive strategy for establishing responsible Palestinian control in Area A that is capable of preventing terrorism and, ultimately, providing the conditions necessary for a viable two-state solution in the future.
The PA must take the necessary steps to effectively govern and secure the communities under its control.

The Palestinian Authority has all but lost the ability to exercise control in Jenin and other West Bank areas. 

The government of Israel and the IDF must act to defend against and thwart any and all terrorist attacks, and dismantle the terrorists’ infrastructure.
The desire of these groups is to establish a terrorism infrastructure in the West Bank similar to what they already have in Gaza.
For months, Palestinian Islamic Jihad, Hamas and other terrorist groups, with the help of Iran, have been using Jenin as a base to launch attacks against civilians in Israel.

I pray the IDF operation in Jenin to dismantle terrorist infrastructure is swift and successful, with minimal casualties, loss of life or property. Terrorists must not have safe haven in Jenin or anywhere else in the West Bank. 1/

Irrespective of  this Supreme Court's decisions, I will continue to fight for better opportunities, and for more pathways to the best educational institutions, for all our young people. 9/
With yesterday’s decisions, the Supreme Court overturns that precedent. For many of our young people, it feels like the Court is slamming the doors of opportunity shut for them. 8/

For decades, the Supreme Court has held that affirmative action is a constitutional tool for universities and colleges to build diverse student bodies for the benefit of their entire educational community. 7/
In America, our diversity is our strength, and it is something that should be embraced and promoted. 6/

Throughout my life, from college and my very first job to now serving as a Representative in Congress, my own experiences have been enriched by the diversity of the experiences shared by my peers.  5/

Too often students are denied access to educational opportunities because the schools in their community lack the basic resources commonly afforded others. We must not allow these disparities to continue. We can, and must, work to close that gap. 4/
In America I know that race still plays a major factor in the opportunities too many children have, for reasons both systemic and generational. 3/
I, too, wish we lived in such a world.  But we don’t. 2/

At the core of their decisions, the 6 SCOTUS Justices seem to project onto their analysis a country where no student faces discrimination based on race, and all students attend schools with the resources to provide equitable pathways to our nation’s best universities &colleges 1/

Today, Rae volunteers with the US Holocaust Memorial Museum’s visitor services, welcoming and guiding museum visitors and sharing her own story.
Rae and Dina joined partisans armed against the Nazis, then found shelter in a displaced persons camp in Italy before immigrating to the United States in 1947.

When Nazis began mass killings in Dokszyce, Rae and her family went into hiding, concealing themselves for nine days in a tiny, secret room between two walls. Rae’s brother was killed and her paternal grandmother sacrificed herself to help Rae and her mother Dina escape.

Rae was a young child when first Soviets and then the Nazis occupied her hometown of Dokszyce, Poland. The Nazi’s required the area’s Jews to wear yellow stars and forced them into a tightly confined, massively crowded ghetto.

I was proud to again host a special House program marking Holocaust Remembrance Day.  Like our first event in 2019, this year GOP and Dem Members were joined by six Holocaust survivors, including Rachel “Rae” Mutterperl Goldfarb who shared her remarkable, truly harrowing story.
